chapter.title: Using &nm;
chapter.para: &nm; is the ideal solution for laptops and other portable computers. It supports state-of-the-art encryption types and standards for network connections, including connections to 802.1X protected networks. 802.1X is the IEEE Standard for Local and Metropolitan Area Networks—Port-Based Network Access Control. With &nm;, you need not worry about configuring network interfaces and switching between wired or wireless networks when you are moving. &nm; can automatically connect to known wireless networks or manage several network connections in parallel—the fastest connection is then used as default. Furthermore, you can manually switch between available networks and manage your network connection using an applet in the system tray.
Instead of only one connection being active, multiple connections may be active at once. This enables you to unplug your laptop from an Ethernet and remain connected via a wireless connection.

sect1.title: Use Cases for &nm;
sect1.para: &nm; provides a sophisticated and intuitive user interface, which enables users to easily switch their network environment. However, &nm; is not a suitable solution in the following cases:

listitem.para: Your computer provides network services for other computers in your network, for example, it is a DHCP or DNS server.
Your computer is a &xen; server or your system is a virtual system inside &xen;.

sect1.title: Enabling or Disabling &nm;
sect1.para: On laptop computers, &nm; is enabled by default. However, it can be at any time enabled or disabled in the &yast; Network Settings module.

step.para: Run &yast; and go to Network Devices Network Settings .
The Network Settings dialog opens. Go to the Global Options tab.
To configure and manage your network connections with &nm;:
In the Network Setup Method field, select User Controlled with &nm;.
Click OK and close &yast;.
Configure your network connections with &nm; as described in .
To deactivate &nm; and control the network with your own configuration
In the Network Setup Method field, choose Controlled by wicked.
Click OK.
Set up your network card with &yast; using automatic configuration via DHCP or a static IP address.
Find a detailed description of the network configuration with &yast; in .

sect1.title: Configuring Network Connections
sect1.para: After having enabled &nm; in &yast;, configure your network connections with the &nm; front-end available in GNOME. It shows tabs for all types of network connections, such as wired, wireless, mobile broadband, DSL, and VPN connections.
To open the network configuration dialog in GNOME, open the settings menu via the status menu and click the Network entry.

note.title: Availability of Options
note.para: Depending on your system setup, you may not be allowed to configure connections. In a secured environment, some options may be locked or require &rootuser; permission. Ask your system administrator for details.

step.para: Open the &nm; configuration dialog.
To add a Connection:
Click the + icon in the lower left corner.
Select your preferred connection type and follow the instructions.
When you are finished click Add.
After having confirmed your changes, the newly configured network connection appears in the list of available networks you get by opening the Status Menu.
To edit a connection:
Select the entry to edit.
Click on the gear icon to open the Connection Settings dialog.
Insert your changes and click Apply to save them.
To Make your connection available as system connection go to the Identity tab and set the checkbox Make available to other users. For more information about User and System Connections, see

sect2.title: Managing Wired Network Connections
sect2.para: If your computer is connected to a wired network, use the &nm; applet to manage the connection.

step.para: Open the Status Menu and click on Wired to change the connection details or to switch it off.
To change the settings click Wired Settings and then click on the gear icon.
To switch off all network connections, activate the Airplane Mode setting.

sect2.title: Managing Wireless Network Connections
sect2.para: Visible wireless networks are listed in the GNOME &nm; applet menu under Wireless Networks. The signal strength of each network is also shown in the menu. Encrypted wireless networks are marked with a shield icon.

procedure.title: Connecting to a visible Wireless Network

step.para: To connect to a visible wireless network, open the Status Menu and click Wi-Fi.
Click Turn On to enable it.
Click Select Network, select your Wi-Fi Network and click Connect.
If the network is encrypted, a configuration dialog opens. It shows the type of encryption the network uses and text boxes for entering the login credentials.

procedure.title: Connecting to an Invisible Wireless Network

step.para: To connect to a network that does not broadcast its service set identifier (SSID or ESSID) and therefore cannot be detected automatically, open the Status Menu and click on Wi-Fi.
Click Wi-Fi Settings to open the detailed settings menu.
Make sure your Wi-Fi is enabled and click Connect to Hidden Network....
In the dialog that opens, enter the SSID or ESSID in Network Name and set encryption parameters if necessary.

sect2.para: A wireless network that has been chosen explicitly will remain connected as long as possible. If a network cable is plugged in during that time, any connections that have been set to Stay connected when possible will be connected, while the wireless connection remains up.

sect2.title: Configuring Your Wi-Fi/Bluetooth Card as an Access Point
sect2.para: If your Wi-Fi/Bluetooth card supports access point mode, you can use &nm; for the configuration.

step.para: Open the Status Menu and click Wi-Fi.
Click Wi-Fi Settings to open the detailed settings menu.
Click Use as Hotspot... and follow the instructions.
Use the credentials shown in the resulting dialog to connect to the hotspot from a remote machine.

sect2.title: &nm; and VPN
sect2.para: &nm; supports several Virtual Private Network (VPN) technologies. For each technology, &productname; comes with a base package providing the generic support for &nm;. In addition to that, you also need to install the respective desktop-specific package for your applet.

listitem.para: To use this VPN technology, install
&nm;-openvpn and
&nm;-openvpn-gnome.
To use this VPN technology, install
&nm;-vpnc and
&nm;-vpnc-gnome.
To use this VPN technology, install
&nm;-pptp and
&nm;-pptp-gnome.

sect2.para: After you have installed the packages, configure your VPN connection as described in .

sect1.title: &nm; and Security
sect1.para: &nm; distinguishes two types of wireless connections, trusted and untrusted. A trusted connection is any network that you explicitly selected in the past. All others are untrusted. Trusted connections are identified by the name and MAC address of the access point. Using the MAC address ensures that you cannot use a different access point with the name of your trusted connection.

&nm; periodically scans for available wireless networks. If multiple trusted networks are found, the most recently used is automatically selected. &nm; waits for your selection in case that all networks are untrusted.

If the encryption setting changes but the name and MAC address remain the same, &nm; attempts to connect, but first you are asked to confirm the new encryption settings and provide any updates, such as a new key.
If you switch from using a wireless connection to offline mode, NetworkManager blanks the SSID or ESSID. This ensures that the card is disconnected.

sect2.title: User and System Connections
sect2.para: &nm; knows two types of connections: user and system connections. User connections are connections that become available to &nm; when the first user logs in. Any required credentials are asked from the user and when the user logs out, the connections are disconnected and removed from &nm;. Connections that are defined as system connection can be shared by all users and are made available right after &nm; is started—before any users log in. In case of system connections, all credentials must be provided at the time the connection is created. Such system connections can be used to automatically connect to networks that require authorization. For information how to configure user or system connections with &nm;, refer to .

sect2.title: Storing Passwords and Credentials
sect2.para: If you do not want to re-enter your credentials each time you want to connect to an encrypted network, you can use the GNOME Keyring Manager to store your credentials encrypted on the disk, secured by a master password.
&nm; can also retrieve its certificates for secure connections (for example, encrypted wired, wireless or VPN connections) from the certificate store. For more information, refer to .

sect1.title: Frequently Asked Questions
sect1.para: In the following, find some frequently asked questions about configuring special network options with &nm;.

question.para: How to tie a connection to a specific device?

answer.para: By default, connections in &nm; are device type-specific: they apply to all physical devices with the same type. If more than one physical device per connection type is available (for example, your machine is equipped with two Ethernet cards), you can tie a connection to a certain device.

To do so in GNOME, first look up the MAC address of your device (use the Connection Information available from the applet, or use the output of command line tools like nm-tool or wicked show all). Then start the dialog for configuring network connections and choose the connection you want to modify. On the Wired or Wireless tab, enter the MAC Address of the device and confirm your changes.

question.para: How to specify a certain access point in case multiple access points with the same ESSID are detected?

answer.para: When multiple access points with different wireless bands (a/b/g/n) are available, the access point with the strongest signal is automatically chosen by default. To override this, use the BSSID field when configuring wireless connections.

The Basic Service Set Identifier (BSSID) uniquely identifies each Basic Service Set. In an infrastructure Basic Service Set, the BSSID is the MAC address of the wireless access point. In an independent (ad-hoc) Basic Service Set, the BSSID is a locally administered MAC address generated from a 46-bit random number.
Start the dialog for configuring network connections as described in . Choose the wireless connection you want to modify and click Edit. On the Wireless tab, enter the BSSID.

question.para: How to share network connections to other computers?

answer.para: The primary device (the device which is connected to the Internet) does not need any special configuration. However, you need to configure the device that is connected to the local hub or machine as follows:

listitem.para: Start the dialog for configuring network connections as described in . Choose the connection you want to modify and click Edit. Switch to the IPv4 Settings tab and from the Method drop-down box, choose Shared to other computers. That will enable IP traffic forwarding and run a DHCP server on the device. Confirm your changes in &nm;.

As the DCHP server uses port 67, make sure that it is not blocked by the firewall: On the machine sharing the connections, start &yast; and select Security and Users Firewall . Switch to the Allowed Services category. If DCHP Server is not already shown as Allowed Service, select DCHP Server from Services to Allow and click Add. Confirm your changes in &yast;.

question.para: How to provide static DNS information with automatic (DHCP, PPP, VPN) addresses?

answer.para: In case a DHCP server provides invalid DNS information (and/or routes), you can override it. Start the dialog for configuring network connections as described in . Choose the connection you want to modify and click Edit. Switch to the IPv4 Settings tab, and from the Method drop-down box, choose Automatic (DHCP) addresses only. Enter the DNS information in the DNS Servers and Search Domains fields. To Ignore automatically obtained routes click Routes and activate the respective check box. Confirm your changes.

question.para: How to make &nm; connect to password protected networks before a user logs in?

answer.para: Define a system connection that can be used for such purposes. For more information, refer to .

sect1.title: Troubleshooting

listitem.para: The applets starts automatically if the network is set up for &nm; control. If the applet does not start, check if &nm; is enabled in &yast; as described in . Then make sure that the &nm;-gnome package is also installed.

If the desktop applet is installed but is not running for some reason, start it manually. If the desktop applet is installed but is not running for some reason, start it manually with the command nm-applet.

varlistentry.term: &nm; Applet Does Not Include the VPN Option

listitem.para: Support for &nm;, applets, and VPN for &nm; is distributed in separate packages. If your &nm; applet does not include the VPN option, check if the packages with &nm; support for your VPN technology are installed. For more information, see .

If you have configured your network connection correctly and all other components for the network connection (router, etc.) are also up and running, it sometimes helps to restart the network interfaces on your computer. To do so, log in to a command line as &rootuser; and run systemctl restart wicked.services.
